chapter.title: Creating an EJB 3 Session Bean
chapter.para: The first thing to notice is that the class is tagged as @Stateless. This marks the class as a stateless bean and the EJB Container will deploy that class as a stateless bean component.
chapter.formalpara:
Session Bean Types The EJB 3 specification defines three different session bean types.
Stateless Session Stateful Session Singleton
In case of a stateless session bean each invocation is assigned to a random instance. On a stateful session bean each invocation is assigned to the same instance, which contains the conversational state on behalf of the session object's client. A single instance is available to handle invocations when its designated as a Singleton.

Session Bean Interfaces In this case the CalculatorBean also implements two interfaces. One is the remote business interface of the EJB the other is the local business interface. Should the bean implement no interfaces it is exposed with the No-Interface view. The bean class itself will then serve as a local business 'interface'.
chapter.para: Similar for org.jboss.tutorial.stateless.bean.CalculatorLocal you need to annotate the class with @javax.ejb.Local for it to be the local business interface of the CalculatorBean.
chapter.formalpara:
JNDI Bindings The Calculator bean will have four global JNDI bindings for the remote- and local business interfaces. By default, JBoss will use ejbName/local and ejbName/remote for the local and remote interfaces, respectively.
java:global/stateless-tutorial/CalculatorBean!org.jboss.tutorial.stateless.bean.CalculatorLocal java:global/stateless-tutorial/CalculatorBean!org.jboss.tutorial.stateless.bean.CalculatorRemote java:global/stateless-tutorial/CalculatorBean!local java:global/stateless-tutorial/CalculatorBean!remote
The JNDI bindings !local and !remote are JBoss specific. The object bound will implement all local or remote business interfaces respectively.

formalpara.title: Building and Running

note.para: To build and run the example, make sure you have installed JBoss 5.x. See the installation section for details.

formalpara.para: From the command prompt, move to the "stateless" folder under the EJB3_TUTORIAL_HOME
Make sure your JBossAS-5.x is running
formalpara.sect5: Maven Users: Make sure the AS is not running.
